Title: The story that everyone deserves to know
Review Text:
The storyline is at par and based on what happened on the other side of the coin. This is all about what happened inside the Malacañang palace during the last days of the well known family in the PH. Upon watching I didn't see anything that distort our country's history unlike what the liberal supporters claiming, who, in fact, judging the story already without watching it.

Anyway, this is a good one. This deserves a spot on your movie to watch bucket list. Kudos to the team and keep going!

Title: A must-watch!
Review Text: It's been years that PH movies have this impact in our society. Kudos to the director, actors and staff. I hope PH movies can be this active and strong again.

Title: This is one of the best movies I've seen this year.
Review Text:
It is a story of LOVE, TRUST, BETRAYAL, and HOPE.

I cried from time to time, and the characters are all relatable, especially as a son to my father, and a brother to my siblings.

Shout-out to all of their performances, specially to Cristine Reyes and to my crush, Ella Cruz! They are all awesome!

Title: Eye-opening scenes and a great family movie!!!
Review Text: The movie is extremely meticulously narrated, and there is a lot of symbolism that will undoubtedly leave an impression on every audience. Because of the tense moments, you will feel every emotion. There was no time wasted, and every element of the film was vital. Director Dah deserves credit for attempting methods that were unfamiliar to him since he believed they would improve the film. Congratulations and gratitude also go to Vincentiments and Viva Films for making this a movie. My admiration for the Marcoses grew even stronger as the film demonstrated that they are also individuals to whom ordinary citizens of the country can connect. You will never be disappointed if you watch it.

Title: Great movie very informative
Review Text: I'll never regret watching this movie with my best friend on its first day just like what I have expected. I can't see any historical revisionism but it's the other side of the story. ♥

Title: The most popular movie of the year.
Review Text: The last 72 hours of family in malacañang. Most watch the other side of 1986. We need to know what happened in the first family in 1986 edsa revolution.

Title: 72 hours in Malacanñang but still alot of story needed to be told.
Review Text: The creative production of Sen. Imee and vision of Director Darryl Yap creating a story of how a person, family, a household would react in their most difficult time. The actors, sets, dialogs, and story blending into one gives us a time machine and feeling of whats happening behind what media, books, people wont show to the people for the past 37 years.

Title: A family movie in time of crisis and the loyalty of their maids
Review Text: This movie will make you cry and after crying will make you laugh again and again. Because chapter by chapter the movie will give you the moments of the family in malacanang under pressure. Their struggles to not to be hurt and to survive for that 72 hours. Their maid was loyal to them and want to fight back to protesters who want to go to the palace and up until now 1 of those maid is alive and still by the side of Madam Imelda Marcos. No historical revisionism. Just emotions of a family that we all can relate to. And also the struggles of those maid to serve and stay loyal to Marcos Family up until the end. And their is one special maid in the story that you need to know who. Love this film.

Title: The Other Side of The Story
Review Text: The other side of the story that is not known to many. A must-see family drama. Very relatable to common Filipino families. Extraordinary performances by the actors that will stir your emotions. Full of emotional scenes mixed with humor. A movie that can be seen over and over again.

Title: Filipino pride film
Review Text: Another quality film addition in Philippine Cinema. The actors and actresses have been given their time to shine. They all give justice to the role they are playing. Good job po sa lahat.

They are humans in its simplest form.

Title: Emotional Rollercoaster
Review Text:
As the movie goes on, you don't realize that your heart is connecting to the story and it seems to automatically connect your brain to the memories that your school once made you believe that Marcos was evil and greedy. Eventually you will shed tears of hatred, pity and sorrow for those who have not been fair to the Marcos family.

That's how I felt.

There is no boring scene. The performance of all the artists especially Ella Cruz was excellent and unmatched, while accompanied by quality music and touching "orchesta" version of Nosi Balasi.

I won't tell everything. Simply, Darryl Yap is a genius.

Title: IT'S NOT REALLY AN HISTORICAL DISTORTION NOR A BIOPIC, IT'S JUST ALL ABOUT THE LAST DAYS OF THE MARCOSES IN MALACAÑANG DURING 1986 EDSA REVOLUTION
Review Text:
At first, we really thought or expect that it was historical distortion or revisionism of what really happened during the 1986 EDSA People Power Revolution. But we've surprised and dissapointed, disappointed because we thought there will be revisionism but they did not have that.

And here's my review about the movie, which is same as the reviews of Mr. Mark Perez Agullana.

Plot.

The movie as the trailer suggested it is about the few days of The Marcoses in Malacañan Palace from the personal account of their household helper or maid and the Maid in Malacañan Senator Imee R. Marcos. By watching this movie, it presented a view I rarely see, read or hear about the Marcoses. Of course, it touched politics but more than that it was a family drama, the other side of the villain most of us do not know through the eyes of those close to him. The story was told with mix of "truth" and "artistic license". It was fun, laughters and tears. The story was told in a clear simple manner that everyone can easily follow.

Themes and Tone The main theme of the movie for me is family than politics. It was made to entertain and educate as well. It is easy to spot on the funny and entertaining jokes inserted in the movie. It is also highlighting and presenting what are the obvious in politics and life - traitorship, allyship, trust, honesty, doing what is right, doing what is good, family connection, friendship and other values. But most importantly, it highlighted the most important unit of the society, the family and its importance especially in difficult times. It tells the importance of making up a decision and acting on it.

There are many symbolisms in the film like the conversation between Bonget and Imelda and how they will be able to return to the Philippines and to the power, great use of imagination. And of course, the most controversial scene of Cory played by Giselle Sanchez. That closing scene and the statement are great show of how Politics and Religion are playing the lives of many Filipinos, the fate of the nation and its wealth while they are lucky for having a seat of power. Until today this is true, in every election and important bills being pushed in the congress.

Acting and Characters I like how each character played their roles. Still, Cesar Montano is Cesar Montano. From Muro Ami to this film. I am thinking how difficult it maybe for Diego Loyzaga to act with his father. Great scene. I wish I have a conversation with my father on important matters in my life. I feel like ILoveRuffaG is not Ruffa with her like x100 very slow movement in the movie. But I like how she potrayed Imelda with so much grace, beauty and elegance. She is really different from who she really is. She matched and gave justice to the role. Ella Cruz is okay. Not too much, not less. But she really did great in her scene with Cesar convincing the father to move out. The three maids were really good. Karla Estrada and Beverly Salviejo were very funny in their scene which gave a balance to this dramatic movie. It was not OA. Of course, Christine Reyes who played the very important role, showed in the movie the acting you expect from her.

Direction Daryll Yap's signature story telling was very evident in the movie. It was simple, not complicated, not too fast and not to slow directing. It was almost a straightforward story telling with symbolisms in a funny way. There was a little tension.

Score The music chosen for each scene were matched perfectly to build the emotions and connect to the characters and story. I like the song choice.

Cinematography The camera movement especially during long walks of Imee is bit shaky, maybe budget or I am not certain if that was intentional. The various shots and angle were good. It is comparable to mainstream films at low budget. I like how the camera was moving in circular motion changing the position of the characters of Bonget and Imelda while they were talking. It depicted how their lives were turning up side down. The lines, the shot, the movement and acting were aligned. All actors were framed properly.

Production Design The costumes and props were good. They matched with the story, the setting and the characters.

Special Effects There's not much special effects used in the movie except the sound effects which are okay.

Editing The film was cleanly edited. The flow is consistent. The transitions used are very simple but effective alongside with the effects and music.

Pace The pace is neither slow nor fast. It was enough. Each scene is not dragging and arranged properly. It was like small episodes of the usual vincentiments film and combined as one.

Dialogue There are conversations that I really feel not needed and the movie will stand still. Oh well, there is really a good script.

Lessons There are many lessons you can take from the movie. It presented an alternative view of the existing truth about the freedom we are enjoying today. Does it change the way I view EDSA, Cory, FEM, Ramos, Juan Ponce Enrile, the Nuns, the Martial Law victims, the truth, the democracy and others? No. It just reaffirmed what I am already believing about FEM, Cory, Ramos, Johnny, the Marcos Family, the Aquino Family, the Nuns, the Martial Law Victims, the EDSA Rallyists and the Filipino People - they are all human beings neither good nor bad. That good or bad outcomes are based from each person's decisions and actions. The movie was good, but I expect more next time.

PS. Indeed, the crowd went applauded after watching the movie. I just want to understand those person who are full of hatred in this movie even the truth is always truth. And this kind of movie, was made from the creative minds and imaginations. Their situations are believable, but the drama or act? Hehehe only they know the truth.

Little spoiler: The Mahjong scene does have POWERFUL MESSAGE.

Title: Your political opinions are better said and heard in elections, not here.
Review Text: A family in crisis trying to come to terms with events unfolding during a tumultuous time in history. The film, despite patently baseless allegations of "historical revisionism" by spineless critics, and farce, inorganic "reviews" by those seeking to resuscitate their defunct and decaying political capital, provides insight into the untold final moments of the Marcos family in Malacañang during the 1986 EDSA protests. No material misrepresentation of "known" historical facts were made in the film. I encourage you to see Maid in Malacañang for yourself to see how laughable and immature its film critics are. I should have rated this 9 stars myself but i have to compensate for the irrational and politically-charged reviews. I just have minor concerns over lighting of some scenes, but overall, the film is superb: a fitting opening salvo to the reopening of Philippine cinemas after the pandemic.

Title: Amazing movie
Review Text: It's truly an amazing movie. It tells us the other side of the story straight from the people who were with the Marcoses. A family movie filled with laughter, sadness, fear and many more.

Title: Superb Storytelling, Excellent Actors
Review Text:
Writer and Director Daryl Yap was effectively able to let the audience understand and feel what the Marcos Family went thru during their last 72 hours in Malacanang. It did not revise what happened in Edsa but showed the other side of the coin.

This film made us cry, laugh, cringe, hate and love. All the actors were excellent in portraying their roles, most especially the Maid in Malacanang.

I love how the story unfolded in chapters, more like so when you are reading a book, and I got to appreciate how each title was artistically appropriate. The development of the drama and the timing of the humor were perfect. It can be published in a book and can be even made more powerful in a theater production.

This movie made me appreciate my family even more and it reminds people how love and family can make us strong despite the pain and the difficulty.

Definitely a must-see for the whole family and for those who want to have a broader perspective of the truth.

Title: Thought-provoking, remarkable, and hilarious - overall, entertaining!
Review Text:
I'd say 99% of the low rating reviews that the movie received came from people who have not watched the movie, I'll tell you why after I share my honest and objective review of the one of the most popular and controversial Filipino movies of 2022.

Most of these people are saying the movie twisted the usual narrative and that it revised the history by peddling lies about the Marcoses. The person who'd say just that is being too dramatic and is most likely a god who's all knowing of what actually happened inside the house and the minds of the Marcoses during the last 72 hours of its dynasty.

No one can really tell you what exactly happened in the last 72 hours as every person's perception of an event that took place in the past has his/her own version of that event. Say you interview 10 people from a single event, each one of those participants may have different version based on his/her perception, views, and beliefs. Hence, you can't say someone else's testimony or version of an event is "false" or "wrong". There is no absolute right or wrong - what's right for you may not be right for others, do not be all too self righteous.

However, this movie in particular is truly controversial as the movie apparently did not put the Marcoses in the bad light, which is something new to most people given how this last name is notorious for being the worst of the worst kinds of people - only if social media existed during the Marcos dynasty, back then, it was easy for powerful people to twist the minds and realities of the masses.

The theater in Cebu (SM Seaside) where I watched was i'd say was about 95% full, and the movie received a round of applause upon reaching the credits. If that doesn't make a movie good for you, then I do not know what is. Again, what's a good movie for you may not be good for the others viewers, and that's alright. As always, watch the movie before you rate it.

Title: Two thumbs up
Review Text:
Don't be fooled by the. Snowflake dilawans' review of this movie. Not only do they have no intention of seeing the movie (yet rated it low anyway) but they got so excited rating it ahead of its official theater release. That alone gives you a clue as to what kind of people this group are.

The movie is not an "attempt" to "revise history" or to "distort" it. The movie is simply a glimpse of how the Marcoses handled their situation inside Malacanang Palace as EDSA "people power" was going on outside their gate. It's how they struggled through the ordeal individually as a son/daughter, as a father, as a mother, as member of the extended family (the maids), and how they handled it as a family as well.

Sure there were scenes that can be thought of as provocative. They can be seen as a swipe to Cory and those who masterminded and staged PP but they were very few and far in between. Besides, the movie itself caters to a specific audience. It's for those who are sympathetic to the Marcoses so it's to be expected that it will play to its audience.

Anyway, this is more of a family drama more than anything else. It humanized the Marcoses. And it was done in a way that it did.not completely absolved them nor completely glorified them. Honestly, I don't know where the fear is coming from.

Anyway, it's refreshing to see a Filipino movie that is different from the usual.

This film can pioneer a revolution in the industry. Our films should abandon the usual movie formula of loveteams, sampalan, predictable plot and storyline, very heroic and purely good protagonist and the pure evil antagonist. This movie used a lot of symbolism, there are character development even within that short span of time.ive not seen this done in most of our movies.

It gave the entertainment sector new life. Following its screening, moviegoers were pleased. The plot is fairly straightforward and centers on the idea of a family struggling to survive and stick together while going through hardships, which accurately depicts how Filipino families are in reality.

Title: Martial Law- the other side
Review Text:
The movie revolves around the last 72 hours of the Marcos family in the Malacañang Palace.

The story depicts the unspoken side of the Marcos family who were painted monsters by the yellow democracy. Many revelations were shown in the movie which are not known to many Filipinos and strikingly, despite the fact how the Marcoses have been terribly persecuted, they have maintained their quiescence for the longest of time.

The transition of the story were stitched neatly and simply and these have made some gray areas clear.

The actors portrayed their roles effectively. One can related well with the characters especially the maids.

Musical scoring have matched the emotions of every scene. I laud well the arrangement of Nosi Balasi. It sounded really a dark past.

But I still have a few questions in mind that were not shown in the movie that I think will turn the tides and I hope to see it in the next two parts (because this is a trilogy)

1. Why did FEM stay long in power?

2. Who assassinated Ninoy Aquino?

For the open-minded viewers, this will movie is like a missing puzzle piece but for critics and yellow apologists, this will be a trashy kind of movie.

Title: A FAMILY DRAMA THAT MARKS THE AWAKENING
Review Text:
The movie is not a documentary. Do not expect it to be right on point with history. Allow some artistic license. It is a family drama based on the accounts of the housemaids of the Marcoses during the last 72 hours in Malacañan.

The movie is chunked into different chapters, much like reading a novel. This style of story telling made it easier for the viewers to process each chapter.

The movie has a clear goal. Production is good.

Review Text: I was hesitant to see the movie at first because I'm part of the opposition. Title: GREAT MOVIE! NO HISTORY REVISIONISM AT ALL.
Review Text:
Story-wise: (1.) The whole movie is almost all about what was happening inside the palace on the Marcoses' last days there. So mostly all of the scenes are inside the palace: the conversations and their situation inside.

(2.) The transition of the 1986 clips are very smooth.

Acting-wise: (1.) It's a mix of comedy and emotional scenes.

(2.) The acting is very well portrayed, it's mostly accurate, the way they talk, they move, they dress.

Overall, NO DISTORTIONS in this movie. NO REVISIONISM OF HISTORY. It is just plainly telling a story.

The production is excellent and brilliant. Kudos to the director of the movie.

If you wanna know why it's title "MAID IN MALACAÑANG", you should watch it.

PS: DO NOT BELIEVE ON THE BAD REVIEWS OF HATERS WHO DID NOT EVEN WATCH IT.

Title: A very interesting film
Review Text: I came in thinking there would have been a "history revisionism" because it was what most talked about but I was pleasantly surprised to see that it was not the case. It was merely showing things, as they unfold, through the eyes of the accused. They also showed footage and published interviews that backed-up the statements made by the characters. This movie opens up a lot of things for discussion and further examination. History, the same with any scientific claim, must react and change according to new evidence discovered, submitted or unearthed. I really think people should stop judging the film before they get a chance to watch it. They should also keep an open mind and let their curiousity be piqued.

My family waited in line for almost an hour because it was sold but it was worth it.

Title: It is more of a Biography that enlighten us on events during that time
Review Text: I don't know about other reviews but i think they are just prejudice because of what they "believe" to be true. And thus prejudice is because of who thus movie is portraying. But for me i base my rating on what i had watched and how much i enjoyed it. It's a great movie overall it has a lot of moment that will make you cry especially if you picture yourself in their shoes. I enjoy laughing and crying at every funny and sad scene during the movie. Some say it is historical distortion but as far a i have watched they even included video footages from that period to backup the scenes. For me the most memorable part of the movies is near the end where they try to leave malacanang. It shows how protesters jumped over the palace gates in an attempt to hurt/"oust" them. That is not historical distortion because that really happened. There are video footage of that and it was also included in the movie. I just hope that people don't just make rating here because they are againts the people being portrayed. Some of those that have given their rating and reviews does not even seem to have watched the movie at all. Hope this helps those that are really interested in watching. For me, i really enjoyed it.

Title: Worth the watch - For open-minded viewers
Review Text:
It's a family drama with an excellent pinch of comic relief. Contrary to the "hate" it's getting from those who have not really watched it due to political leaning, this movie did deliver on entertainment value.

The actors performed surprisingly well. From the extras, "maids" and to the lead roles, kudos. Story telling was smooth and editing was masterfully stitched. Soundtrack, hands down. The director really made an effort to tell the story without pretense. It was raw.

Was there a historical revisionism? I didn't think so. My father had personal accounts of the ML and the story was already ingrained in me since childhood. So I think, (at least to my perspective) that this story was something else.

In the cinema, I do hear people being emotional from some scenes. Seeing some audience nearby my seat, trying to wipe their tears. I was also one of those. I was actually moved not because of the characters itself but on how the director and the actors made the story relatable to common people - family. It does make you realize how important it is to learn from experiences and that it's always wise to listen to your parents. Love - is the primordial factor of survival.

If some people wouldn't think about the baggage of what this movie is all about, then I think it deserve better scores.

Title: Betrayal and Loyalty
Review Text: A great movie indeed! The cast, the acting and the lines are superb. Congrats Direk Darryl Yap for a successful movie and for bringing the Philippine Cinema back amid the Covid 19 Pandemic.

Title: For Those Selfish and Arrogant People Giving 1/10
Review Text:
Karma will surely get you one day.

The movie doesn't have anything to do with historical revisionism nor fiction like what others are trying to say selfishly just to bring down the image of a family or certain people.

The movie is mainly about what the people in Malacañang felt specifically the Marcos family during their last 72 hours there. Don't they have the right or at least the freedom to tell their side of the story that never been heard or fairly listened to since the past 30+ years? I thought the opposition love to scream the word "freedom" every rally? After all these years, why not ask ourselves who are the real dictators and threat to the country?

It seems that those people saying history distortion or history revisionism(those giving 1/10 for obvious selfish reason) didn't watch the movie yet. They gave review just to drag the movie down. For sure many anti-Marcos trolls will rate the movie 1/10 and yeah, that's just how sad and selfish some of them.

They claim to be the victims of Martial Law that sounds to know everything when they speak but can't accept or at least respect the other side of the coin.

I applaud all the cast, staff and director of the movie for reviving our Philippine cinema despite the pandemic. Simple, pero ROCK! Thank you Vincentiments!

Title: Imperfectly perfect.a MASTERPIECE!
Review Text:
How should I put it?

Owh,way back 1986, EDSA people power took place and as a result,the Marcos family and the late President Ferdinand Marcos have nothing to do but to stepback and surrender the presidency.

Since then, the Victor's,Aquino administration, with all her allies continue to run the country and start their own side of history from that day. Sell the biggest government owned electricity establishment to private,change the Manila International Airport to her late husband's name, confiscating and freezing all the Marcos wealth, file hundreds or thousand of cases about the family which in Hawaii,the time wherein Ferdinand Marcos is already dying. His only request was to go back to the Philippines and die here,but the Aquino refused!

For the past 36 years, none of the Marcoss tries to tell what happened that day or have the chance to just discern their side.

I've just read about the unfortunate story in the book. It was taught in elementary,secondary and a little in college about Martial Law. Believing that the Marcos are evil and Martial law is nothing but a shackles to every Filipino.

Then the internet rise.

Iam now 37 years old, little by little,I'm questioning myself. Is the story about the EDSA and Martial law are correct,creditable and factual?

I started searching. Books by books. Article by article.

Then I realized, the history about it,which I've known since elementary was just a piece of trash.

I was living in a factual lies!

2016,BBM(Ferdinand Marcos Jr.) run the Vice Presidential seats but lost. From then on, I told to my self that I will support them. Not because what I have learned about them,but on what they can do in order to lead the Filipino people.

6 years gone past and he run again but for the highest post. And tremendously won the heart of 31m Filipinos by landslide. Why? Because he received more trampled trash from the past, tons of bashing, humiliation and unhuman forbearance by those who supported and believe that EDSA is worthy and the Aquino are saints that time.

After the election,2022, one movie becomes controversial. The Maid in Malacañang is a story of the last 72 hours of the Marcos family inside the presidential palace. They are also human who cries when experience heartbreak, who gets upset,who feel disappointment, who feels anger and hatred. They are also a typical family in different status in life,but they are human.

Those who believe in the people power said that the movie will revise the history.. IT'S A BIG NO You better watch it first then if there's any of the clip or scenes distorted the history, then email me and let's have some healthy argumentation about that. It's not a biopic and documentation movie. It is a story on what happened to them inside the Malacañang palace from the last 72 hours of their reign.

I rated it 9/10 it is. It needs to more justified. The other side of the coin must be heard and watched,not to change the history but they deserved to be heard. Even in the court. The judge weigh both sides.

Title: Redeeming 30+ years of damage
Review Text:
I have lived my life from the very start of martial law and I am now approaching my senior years.

All along, I already knew the stories portrayed in this movie so none of these are new or surprising to me since I have followed these events in 1986 on tv, radio, newspapers and further reading.

And yet, I just have to shed tears for myself and my fellow Filipinos while watching Maid in Malacanang.

Great acting, story telling and directing. We can all relate to this movie if we watch it with an open mind and no political baggage.

Bottomline for me, if I were to categorize it, is that this is a movie about a family in the eyes of a family member and extended household who were in the throes of revolutionary hopelessness and filled with drama (not sensational or over the top like what we see in our soap operas) and light comic relief.

The soundtrack was equally moving and has been dwelling in my mind, rent-free.

Those 30+ years, sad to say, were wasted time for what could have been a truly great nation of and for the Filipinos.

Damage has and will continue to be done to the mindset of Filipinos from mind-conditioning and brainwashing by schools, the communists, the catholic church and the biased mainstream media which are still controlled by oligarchs and US puppets.

They have done this for the last 50+years and has institutionalized this bias since 1986.

These evil collusions will continue to wreak havoc if we don't deepen our understanding of the true state of this nation and the forces that are acting against the common good of the Filipinos.

I don't see any attempt to revise history.

Story was told as it happened from first hand experience and personal perspectives.

The movie serves its purpose in broadening the mindset and consciousness for nation building.

With Knowledge, Understanding and Unity, Filipinos will rise to true greatness.

Let's make it happen!

Review Text: We loved the movie, its another side of the story of Marcos Family during EDSA Revolution. IThe whole story happened inside the Malacañang Palace within 72hours before their departure to Hawaii. NO HISTORICAL REVISIONISM WAS MADE. This movie proves that we should hear the side of Marcos Family. There is nothing wrong with this movie. Only Anti Marcos will rate this movie negatively. Please be fair. Review Text: I can't remember how many times I Laugh and Cry in this movie, I feel bad to those who are saying that this Movie made look the Marcoses as Victims so that the people will pity them. Yes they are the Victims for 36 years they have been labled as Dictator, Evil, Monsters, Liars, Thief and Murderer. Review Text: Point of view of the eldest daughter of President Ferdinand Marcos. How they spent the last 72 hours in Malacañang Palace. History has painted the Marcos family as a dictator, inhuman and corrupt. The opposition also used religion to distort a predominantly catholic country in asia to protest against the ruling Marcos. In effect the 1986 People Power revolution was a peaceful process of power grabbing of the Cory Aquino presidency. Marcos could have stirred a cicil war, but instead left against his will peacefully. The movie depixts the human nature of the Marcoses erased by brainwashing that the yellow political clout was a good choice. 30 years has passes since 1986, the worst case scenario happened. 2022 the Marcoses are back and this is the untold story.

Title: Emotion-triggering, tears and laughter
Review Text:
Despite all the fuss about this film, I went to watch it with an open mind. It could go either way but it did not disappoint. I liked that the movie was broken down into chapters. I liked the dynamic of the family, it's just like a normal family who goes through traumatic events. I mean, how is it not traumatic when there are so many death threats. The pacing is easy to digest, I love the details that were of the era. 👍

The biggest take away I have is that, not everything is as media portrays it. Which is very rampant even to this date. It only solidifies all the stories I heard from my 79 year old father who lived and thrived. He always shared stories of life back in the day. The narrative over the past 34 years have been the same, it's old and tired. The narrative has been broken. I think it's high time to hear the other side, which is weird because there are a few who are against it? Why? Even during a trial, there's prosecution and defense. We werent allowed to hear the defense side of things, it's due time to hear the other side. Also, if those years were truly the worst of the times, how come some of the very crucial hospitals that were made then are still very useful these days? What's even more boggling is that those who wished to overthrow then president and promised better lives for Filipinos did the exact opposite of what they promised the people? How come instead of making our lives better it became stagnant and even went downhill? Where is the improvement they promised? Heart center, lung center, and kidney institute were not improved and there werent any creation of additional public hospitals like those anymore. Those facilities that were built in that "dark era" are still functional to this date. Overrun as they are, they help the common citizen. These are some of the things that broke the opposing narrative. We refuse to be led to believe the holier-than-thou narrative. It's overused and tired. The hypocrisy is blatant and we no longer stand beside it.

The movie showcases amazing acting from very good artists, it'll trigger so many emotions in the audience no matter your age or sex. At the end of the day, it is an imagining of the last 72 hours in Malacañang in 1986. It is a movie, democracy is for everyone not for a select few. This movie should be watched those who bash it have an alternate agenda and it's petty.

Title: I Didn't Like It But Definitely Entertaining
Review Text:
So what are my thoughts about Maid In Malacañang.

This is a non paid review for this film.

Unlike trolls who reviewed this film and gave this bad marks without watching it.

So to start.

I don't like it. But read along before you attack with torches and hurl insults.

Here are reasons why. (Warning : Few Spoilers)

This is not a historical movie. If you want to see something stronger, then watch Brocka's banned movie or actual news footage. Not a movie told from the perspective of the producer, the director or the award giving bodies.

If you are expecting a revisionist movie like dispelling rumours about the Marcoses excesses and opulence, this is not for you. It doesn't hide their wealth and their control of people around them - from the luxury-wearing zero-gravity moving Imelda, to the scary bossy angered Imee, the party going camou-wearing brave-wanting Bonget. No sugar coating here - they are revealed as spoiled people.

It doesn't portray the Marcoses as the bravest souls as they show here how they spiraled to their fears and frustrations, the latter shown by former President FEM himself. If you are expecting them to be portrayed here as a blameless hero family, they aren't as even Irene

It doesn't show the Marcoses as the most powerful family in the country as they too failed to save their entire extended household (meaning those who lived long with them in the palace). The mahjong scene that irked many before the actual showing revealed the figures who were more powerful, and I emphasize, were as it is passe. And it is not the one who sat at the mahjong table but the bigger entity some tried to represent mockingly.

It didn't show the atrocities during Martial Law nor it depicted further the evil side of many politicians some have come to worship for decades. Nor did it tackle the roots of what made Martial Law to be declared.

It didn't utilise more some actors like Elizabeth Oropesa, the controversial Ella Cruz and even the most hated actress now for portraying the symbolic yellow wearing saint, Gieselle Sanchez. I feel like some scenes really got stolen much by the superb timing and acting of Beverly Salviejo aka Manang Biday.

But it did reveal some things that would make more people ponder, especially with the "what ifs". Highly entertaining as was the movie, I am left with questions after seeing it as the pieces still don't feel complete. With many puzzle pieces hidden before like actual video clips of how the palace was stormed and yes, burned (as there are actual reports to such in the news), the actual announcements to join EDSA uprising (I wish they put recordings of those actual announcements of Sin calling the faithful), to the big reveal for some that Marcoses were aimed to be killed by friends and some organised people, I can't help but ponder is the running time enough for film or is this better a series?

Some things are made clear here though.

First, and I won't be apologetic. This is a middle finger movie to Ramos who died days before the movie was shown. Maybe he chose to die before his humiliation can be revealed that he was indeed part of planners to kill off the first family. I know BBM paid respects but the Maid in Malacañang didn't and I understand her for that.

This is also a big middle finger movie to family and friends who betray us for politics. Darryl never shies away from controversy and arguments. With the 2022 election campaign being hailed as the most toxic we experienced (and maybe the worst of all time). The lines hit hard that you eat on the same plate with people who wish you dead. Sadly, toxicity is shared on the plate.

This is not a hate film though. In fact, it is a beautifully crafted melodrama with light touches of humor and reference to 80s, to telenovelas and even PRRD's expletives. The music was superb, the pacing mostly on point but always easy to follow and the acting delivered credibly by everyone in the main cast. If Cesar Montano and Beverly Salviejo don't get awards here, we know some directors probably thought to award it to someone else and found their own reflections.

Darryl also is masterful in creating memorable lines like how he delivered with his notoriously popular LenLen series. My dad kept repeating some of the lines he remembered and I of course love villains so you know whose I remember the most. Add the symbolisms, references and mild swearing he put may look or sound cliche for some but those are reminders that this movie is not perfect nor the people shown in it. It doesn't lie like others hailing their own as absolute truth and true masterpiece that must be seen again (and I say again as not much watched the first run, it wouldn't earn either with a re-run if not put side by side with Maid in Malacañang). It doesn't lie that it is not without creative liberties meant to stir emotions at almost every chapter as they hit the right nerves at most points.

Maid in Malacañang is not a movie made to justify lies as others claim it would be. Rather, it presents itself as a vulnerable piece prone to dissection - hence chapters. It is highly entertaining as it is thought provoking, tear inducing, BP raising, heart warming.

So I don't like it.

I love it.

PS the final mahjong scene looks funny in the trailers but it is actually a sinister dark energy filled take, from the daunting music which reminds of The Omen, to the evil spewed out lines to the closing of hands playing with yellows. A promotion of what was to come. Darryl should make a horror film continuation about this. :P.

Title: Untold story not historical revisionism
Review Text:
We see the other face of history Lincoln once said, "nearly all men can stand adversity, but if you want to test a man's character give him power." This to me sums up Maid in Malacanang.

I came out thinking of love and power after laughing and tearing up on the various chapters of the movie. Love being power in itself. The movie was love of parents, siblings, workers who remained loyal until the end, love of self (masama ba akong tao?), people who surrounded those in power and love of country. Love after all is power.

It has often been said, "Love is Light, that enlightens those who give and receive it. Love is gravity, because it makes some people feel attracted to others. Love is power, because it multiplies the best we have, and allows humanity not to be extinguished in their blind selfishness. Love unfolds and reveals."

I hosted a private screening of #MIM last 9 August. I carefully selected the audience ensuring a generational mix. There are six (6) generations: Baby Boomers: born 1946 to 1964; Generation Jones: born 1955 to 1965; Generation X: born1 965 to 1980; Xennials: born 1977 to 1983; Millennials: born 1981 to 1996; Generation Z: born 1997 or after and Generation Alpha: born 2010 or after. X. Only Generation Alpha was not represented. A total of 56 individuals watched #MIM.

There was no revisionism made. It provided the 72 hours on the other side of the proverbial fence, the side of the Marcoses which were never really made clear to all Filipinos. The side I hated and never crossed in my youthful years. But a leader I knew from grade school to college. He was my only president for my first 23 years.

Of course I didn't know the POV of the three (3) maids but certainly knew of Sen. Imee Marcos' role as "mayordoma" - she was after all the assistant of her father, being the eldest and more knowledgeable than the other siblings.

MiM reinforced the characterizations I learned of Imee Marcos and Bongbong Marcos growing up. There was no sugarcoating on those two. What got my attention was that of the youngest, Irene Marcos. She was never political. She was always the sweet girl with a ready smile. That scene of Irene Marcos with the father was gut wrenching. Was there creative license there? I don't know because Irene Marcos has never been in the public eye. But that scene summed up what to be in government meant, what to hold power and how to deal with people wanting more. Meron bang mabuting pamahalaan is still ringing.

Clearly the sibling rivalry was there. Clearly, Imee was her father's daughter and Bongbong was the mama's boy. On point was a strong Imee and a gentle and low-key Bongbong. The moorings of the son was palpable in the scenes with the eldest, father and mother. Interesting that the journal page on Bongbong had an extended play with FM saying he believed in his son despite being a spoiled brat, the son after all was out to secure the support of the father. In politics, the namesake will always have that internal doubt (am I worthy of the name? Can I be better than my father? Could I achieve even just an inch of what he has done?). I have seen that internal debates with fathers and sons in the world of politics.

The scene of loyalists remaining in the palace wearing yellow and doing the L sign were just stories I heard from friends who joined the march to Malacanang on that night. "May mga tao kaming nadatnan pero pro-Aquino." I remembered the trashing, the bringing out of souvenirs. I myself had a piece of the barbed wire but can't recall where it is today...

Ang "kasaysayan ay chismis"? Puede pero sa ilang dekadang pagsasaliksik at paghahanap ng katotohanan, puede and chismis ay nagkakaruon ng ugat at yumayabong hanggat may nagiibang daloy para ito muling baguhin. Hindi natutulog ang kasaysayan. Ito ay umiikot kung may kontrang daluyan ng punto o pangyayari na uusig sa ating kinagisnan.

Darryl Yap knows the public pulse so well. He intertwined happy and sad; comedic relief in a hot confrontation; the power of the moment and the internal questions one get to ask about how to love a country are all in the film. Sometimes, its takes a very ordinary view by maids that we discover the real narrative at the back of certain events. They may not sit well for some but it has to be told.

Were the Marcoses placed in a different light after MiM? Yes, because we saw their humanity and no, because the final chapter has yet to be written. As a wise man said to me after the film, it would be better to see who instigated all these things. "Where is Joma in all these?"

MiM also confirmed the role of a foreign power in getting the Marcoses out. They were escorted and just by a call, they were rerouted. I again remember a favorite adage: "In politics, nothing happens by accident. If it does, you can bet it was planned that way."

The character I loved in this film was Manang Biday. For someone who did not know how to swim, maybe she survived her plight because she drank a lot from the Pasig River 😆.

Sometimes ordinary people hold the keys to where the mighty will soar or land head on. Often, they take the calumny to heart and that's what loyalists are made of. ###

Title: LEARN, ACCEPT, FORGIVE, FORGET & PROSPER
Review Text:
MOVIE REVIEW: 1. Amazing Acting of all actors involved in this film. (Their acting were able to immerse me into the situation) 2. Great mix of comedy and pain 3. Great storyline

MY PERSONAL MESSAGE: In this film, you will see how unjust these people went, but at the same time, how they deserved justice in the present time.

Remember, the Truth always will be revealed, one way or the other, maybe now or sooner. Whether you like it or not, Justice will prevail. It does not mean many people will believe and accept, but the Marcoses demonstrated that they still continued even if there are circumstances around them.

Haters out there, even if the elections are finished, do you even think the Marcoses will fail this time? No matter how much energy you put on hating the Marcoses, it would be useless. But it does not mean I hate you.

As a Filipino, can we all please stop all of this. Can we all move on? What would happen to the Philippines if we keep being divided? As a Filipino, I request that we must continue to prosper more, rather than being stuck talking about this history. It is time to start a new beginning.

Supporters or Haters, let's make a new beginning, for the sake of our future generations. Let us learn how to accept, how to forgive, how to forget the past mistakes, and how do we move on. It may not be easy, but we must learn to endure!!

Title: My all time favorite Filipino film!

I could consider it as a "Dra-medy" drama mix with comedy, and it was done perfectly! Actors portrayal of Marcos family and all the cast were superb, intriguing, miraculous and very funny. It is not a film about pro or anti Marcos, it's about simple things in life which is love to humanity. In terms of its technical aspect, I was blown away from the costumes, props. ( airplane was one of them), and the soundtrack was top notch, you'll be humming it after you saw it, a world class classic! Bring a napkin or tissue, the theater will be filled with tears....

Title: SUPER BLOCK BUSTER FILIPINO MOVIE OF THE YEAR AFTER PANDEMIC
Review Text:
THE EMPEROR'S SWINDLER: A SPOILER-FREE REVIEW OF DARRYL YAP'S MAID IN MALACAÑANG BY SASS ROGANDO SASSOT

I have watched Darry Yap's other films - Jowables, Pornstar series, and Revirginized. What I noticed in those films is Yap's storytelling: he begins strong, then somewhere in the story he rushes to reach a denouement. Maid in Malacañang (MiM) is a different Yap.

Nothing felt rushed, the storytelling progressed like an onion being peeled delicately. Yap peeled MiM so delicately in its intricate layers, letting the audience shed tears as each layer unravelled, without emotionally manipulating them to do so.

And like in his other films, Yap combined drama and comedy - this time, seamlessly. There's still the usual preachy parts, like in his other films - this time, integrated so well as a narrative device, rather than as a cop out from the labor of story development.

As an ensemble, the cast is skilfully selected.

Cesar Montano is a Bernini sculpture: the minutest detail of his acting is Ferdinand E. Marcos. Diego Loyzaga is spot on in his portrayal of President BBM's coming of age moment. Real-life father and son, Cesar and Diego's confrontation scene is like watching a masterclass in acting.

Ruffa Guttierez's elegant acting unveiled Imelda, as a mother, beneath all the glamor. Ella Cruz as Irene Marcos tells us she has a bright future in Philippine cinema.

The three maids: Karla Estrada's comedic timing is masterfully delivered. Elizabeth Oropesa is timeless. Even when she's just standing, she makes you believe. Beverly Salviejo deserves a standing ovation for every scene: Give her her own full-length film. One never wastes a juggernaut like her! Even if there are 24 characters in a film, just cast Salviejo, and she would be able to persuade you that there were 24 different actors.

Now...Cristine Reyes as Imee Marcos. She does not deserve an acting award. Reyes must be given a monument. Rename NAIA, EDSA, the West Philippine Sea after her -- I don't care. Reyes, like Montano, is a Bernini sculpture: even when she is deep in thought, she is giving us Imee Marcos. If Reyes could top her acting prowess in MiM, name an entire galaxy after her.

As the film reached its denouement, I cursed: "Potaena ka Darryl Yap!!!! Brilliantly wicked!"

The Emperor's New Clothes told the story of the swindlers who made a fool of an emperor and his ministers. They promised to weave the finest cloth for the emperor, and whoever wouldn't be able to see it is unusually stupid. Unusually stupid - that's how enfant terrible Yap made everyone who thinks so highly of themselves looked like with his most brilliant work to date.

MiM's real plot isn't in the film itself. This is one of the rare instances where the real plot developed after the film has been promoted publicly. In this sense, MiM is just a subplot. The main plot is the one - consciously or unconsciously - written by Yap: The mass hysteria of people addicted to their victimhood - real or imagined, reacting to the film they never watched. Yap directed a satire -- and it's not MiM. If you're as alert as the innocent child in The Emperor's New Clothes, you will easily spot the nakedness of the Emperor, his ministers who lost the plot, and the swindlers who wove the finest golden cloth worn by history.

Title: Must watch for every Filipino
Review Text:
This is a movie about the last 72 hrs of the Marcos family in Malacanan before the Liberal Party took over.

The story tackles the question: "How was the Marcos family while EDSA revolution was going on?" I cannot remember this topic being discussed in any history class nor in any "special feature" telenovela nor in any movie at that.

Previously made films or dramas always celebrated how the Aquinos were supposedly the heroes of Philippine democracy.

No other film in the contemporary time had tackled the story of Maid in Malacanan. And for that alone, I think this is a must watch for every Filipino, whatever political inclination you may have.

And if you will be watching, always keep in mind that this is a movie. For issues regarding "matter of fact", it would still be prudent to do your own research. This movie will definitely stimulate your interest in Philippine history. It will make you realize that perhaps your history lessons back in your elementary/high school days might actually be just a one-sided story.

Title: My reviews for MIM
Review Text:
I've watched "Maid in Malacañang" last Aug.3 in a fully-packed at SM Cinema SMBF.

What it accomplished was to convey the EMOTIONAL ROLLER COASTER behind the last 72 hours of a family that is either going to be lynch-mobbed to death, or kidnapped for safety.

There is nothing revisionist about what happened in the critical days of EDSA, and absolutely nothing about Martial Law or the attempt to redifine it.

MIM did not distort the story of EDSA, nor of Cory, or the Carmelite Nuns for that matter. Far from it. The dilawan rage over the movie is so misplaced, and so convulated that I cannot help but again believe that it was contrived and manipulated just to fuel more hate and devide.

Title: A Must-Watch For All Filipinos
Review Text:
It seemed pretty obvious that the rating here has been desperately pulled down by no other than the yellows/pinks, otherwise known as the anti-Marcos people. Notice how uniform the ratings are? People who truly took the time to watch the film wouldn't have written such utterly biased, uniform ratings. Somehow there would be slight differences in numbers, depending on each and everyone's movie-watching experience. However, as obvious as they can get, their purpose here is to attack the film and the people surrounding it, because they do not want the Marcoses' side of truth to come out, or be heard. Even before the film was released, there were already 1-star reviews, which is typical of how the other side has always reacted to anything Marcos. The real distortion here is the other side who claims to be for democracy, but couldn't even allow others to tell their side of the story. Ponder on that.

Darryl Yap is a brilliant filmmaker. Genius. I admire his brevity and his courage in divulging the untold story of a family that would help pave the way for an eye-opening experience to the Filipino people, through a significant work of art.

I love how the film was made; the symbolisms, the transitions, its metaphorical scenarios. Bravo, Direk Darryl!

Note: Open-minded people who are not pro-Marcos have watched the film and they were mind-blown. How do I know? I chanced upon watching their reactions on their Facebook live.

You will not lose anything if you watch it. You will regain something though -- your humanity.

Title: Imperfect!
Review Text: As Ella told Cesar, the government can never be perfect. So does the movie. A gallant effort to show the 'normal' side of a family whose 'kingdom' is crumbling amidst efforts to destroy them, quite literally and figuratively and the reaction and interactions amongst them. Besides a Prologue and an Epilogue, divided into 8 chapters highlighting the conversations (topic is accurate but the specific conversation is cinematic invention) between and among members of the Marcos family feeling the world close in on them and the pain and angst associated with it. Each chapter conversation will try to pinch your heart and then caress them with humor, placed near the end. It has many foreshadowing, Between chapters are short narratives to connect each chapter either text, footages or narrations. It focus only on the family and their helpers. Its music is haunting and heavy (MOSTLY PIANO) save for some sequences. It is not epic and doesn't pretend to be, nor documentary, albeit it does show footages that are self-explanatory. Generally good, and has some scenes that I feel are either out-of-place or not-well thought-out or appears to be an editing misjudgment due to discontinuity. It is worth watching. Those rating this 1 or saying historical revisionism HAVEN'T SEEN this and shame they bother to rate something they've NOT SEEN. I'VE SEEN it. 7/10 (but I gave it 10 stars due to many unfair ratings it received)

Title: A Surprisingly Good Movie with Roman Catholic Themes
Review Text:
A surprisingly good movie, considering the sensitive subject matter! Genuine characterizations of the Marcos family, including their personality flaws, and a nice balance of drama and humor. Not at all revisionist, as the contents are mainly interpersonal events between the Marcos family and household staff, and TV news footage. Looking forward to the sequel.

There are a lot of Christian and Roman Catholic themes in the movie. I will not mention these in my review to avoid spoiling the movie. These themes become more evident on the second or third viewing. Observe the way the characters are presented visually. Also listen carefully to what they say, especially their choice of words. Observe things that are present around the characters.

The genre of the movie is definitely political, with the objective of humanizing the Marcos political family. This is good, because the Marcos family are human beings, and the movie is telling this truth. But I think the movie at its core, is deeply Roman Catholic, and uses the story of the Marcos family to communicate spiritual truths.

I did not give the movie the highest rating because there are some parts of the movie that "tell you" rather than "show you" through action and character development. But it is not easy to see this because the acting is so good. You are able to lose yourself in the world of the Marcos family during their final days in power, and we also care about the characters so much that we do not clearly discern the screenplay writer "preaching to you".

A lot of criticism about the movie comes from the final scene where Cory Aquino is playing Mahjong with some nuns, as they say this did not happen, and so give this final scene as an example of historical revisionism. However, what Cory was doing at the time is not historically significant. The critics miss what is being communicated in this scene at a spiritual level. Observe closely the altar next to the Mahjong table. Do you notice anything odd? What is the position of Cory Aquino relative to the altar? Do you notice anything odd about the nuns? If you see the spiritual theme being presented, then now you might have something significant to be upset about, after you get over the initial shock.

Enjoy the movie. It gets better with every viewing.

I have created a vlog reviewing this movie in my BitChute Channel: "Prepare For Departure". It is a spoiler review, so I recommend that you watch the movie first.

Title: Great movie
Review Text:
Cinematic wise the movie is well made. Camera movements, colors and camera angles are great. Never seen a filipino movie made like this before.

For the story. Its backed with video footages which validates its truthfulness. Story came from the family and the people who knew what really happened. Its a side of the story that was kept secret fr a long time. Thanks for the pilipino who voted marcos (Im not one if those because Ive voted another candidate but not yellow of course). Title: Truly a masterpiece, three decades in the making.
Review Text:
Having finally watched Maid in Malacanang twice already over the last couple of days, I felt I should take to IMDB myself to rate the movie. Before watching this film, I had no idea really of what it might have actually really been like during those last 72 hours of the Marcos Presidency.

It's very easy just to rely on what's out there already in terms of historical documentation and documentaries on the Marcos era and those days as well as the so called EDSA revolution, but what we don't know is what it was really like for those present with the family themselves, what were there feelings, emotional responses and so much more. This movie and that era has been brought to life through the excellent storytelling of Philippine director, Darryl Yap. I believe he has put his heart and soul into this movie as have the whole cast and crew. Both Cesar Montano and Christine Reyes put on great performances, really believable and heartfelt.

If I could rate this movie as 11/10 I would. Please do all you can to watch this wonderful masterpiece!!!

Title: An absolute masterpiece
Review Text:
It was the first time in my entire life that a movie had such a profound impact on me from beginning to end.

The chapters are their entirety highlights. In the movie, each character has a standout moment.

1. The scene between Marcos Sr. And MarcosJr. Is excellent and ends with some humor.

2. I was deeply moved by the interaction between Irene and Marcos Sr. Irene's speech reflects her anguish very viscerally.

3. Imelda and Marcos Jr. Scene also made me shiver, and the scene where Imelda recognizes her jewelry and shoes captivated me. In the end, one of the maids sings the background music, and Biday is hilarious.

4. I was moved by the scene between Marcos Sr. And Imee in which he declared Imee to be his favorite and most trusted child.

5. But it was the sight with all the house staff and security officers that moved me and practically shed a tear to my eye. The three main maids address the entire staff in this scenario in order to inform them of the apparent departure of the first family. I was only able to control myself because I was sitting next to another viewer. But if I'm by myself, I imagine I'll be sobbing uncontrollably.

6. The final chapter, in which the servants lamented their exile with the family but were forced to use a piece of yellow clothing from Imelda's closet, is similarly heartbreaking.

Even as I write this review, I can't stop crying. The movie is a true masterpiece and magnificent. I'll watch this movie again, I swear.

Title: true story
Review Text:
The movie is actually a family dramedy. If there is one thing that I find problematic, it is the stereotypical typecasting, once again, of maids becoming the sources of comic relief. But certainly, it is hard not to be amazed by Yap's masterful weaving in of humor as a punchline, most vividly represented by that emotionally charged confrontation between father and son Ferdinand Marcos Sr. And Jr., played by real father and son Cesar Montano and Diego Loyzaga, capped by the tiptoeing Biday, ably played by veteran comedian Beverly Salviejo. It was seen again in that touching dramatic silent monologue of Imelda Marcos played by Ruffa Gutierrez as she bid goodbye to her material possessions of gowns and shoes, taking only small mementos and love letters her husband Ferdie sent her, to the tune of that iconic 'Dahil Sa Iyo,' which turned out to be not a soundtrack but Biday, again, belting out her own aria as she was dusting a flower vase.

On a larger scale, the entire movie was actually a wicked punchline to rudely douse water ON the misplaced fears, the ruckus and the noise, about this movie becoming a monumental sacrilege to the altars of historical purity. There is nothing in this movie that actually distorts, revises, or replaces what we already know. This is not Yap and Viva Films trying to assault history with outlandish claims, but simply a dramatic, and sometimes hilarious, representation of a powerful family at their most vulnerable, most defeated state as they faced their imminent downfall.

It is the story of an eldest daughter, a role excellently enacted by Cristine Reyes playing Senator Marcos who struggled to lead a family in the throes of collapse, trying to hold it together. It is the story of a son, poignantly played by Loyzaga as the young President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., trying to make his father proud, trying to prove that he can be more than the party animal with whom his father expressed disappointment. It is the story of youngest daughter Irene Marcos Araneta played by Ella Cruz pleading with her father, and whose lines in the movie embodied a summary of the entire political career of her father.

Some people took note of the absence of any reference to the actual reasons why EDSA took place, and count this as a deficiency of the movie. What they missed is that this movie is less a historical account of EDSA, or the political downfall of the Marcoses, but a family drama to reveal the stories behind the façade of the presidential palace. Ella Cruz's character of Irene summed up what can possibly be said about the rule of her father - that his government was not perfect, and that he lost control of it and his people, many of whom betrayed him. These are factual claims.

There is no deliberate attempt to radically alter facts. Instead, what is given space is to provide the Marcos narrative a voice, and for the audience to form their own interpretations. The scene of the stash of cash at the beginning of the movie is perfect imagery that captured this. It establishes the fact that indeed there were boxes full of undistributed cash, which many would interpret as money intended to buy voters in the 1986 snap elections, but the character representing Senator Marcos rationalized it as payment for people who actually worked for the Marcos campaign. It was left to the viewers to form their own conclusions as to which narrative we will believe.

The much talked about, and bashed scene, of former president Corazon Aquino playing mahjong with nuns, who incidentally are clearly represented not as the Carmelite sisters, is actually an artistic and symbolic representation, following another symbolic scene where Ferdinand and Imelda waltzed while Malacañang was being attacked by a mob. If there is one moment where Yap made a political commentary, it would be in this symbolic representation of the political elites playing with the Church during EDSA. And no one can dispute that indeed the Church played a crucial role there.

This movie is not about revising history but about humanizing the Marcoses at their most vulnerable and weakest. This is something that cannot be denied by anyone, tyrant or otherwise. It doesn't change what they did or failed to do.

If there is another important fact that this movie revealed, it is that aside from the Marcoses there were others in Malacañang when it fell. These were the people who served them as guards and maids, who for so long were invisible, but finally were given a voice in this film.

In the end, the politics of this film is less seen in its content but more in how it has been received. It is like an RT-PCR test that would reveal whether we are positive with partisan prejudice, or negative and tolerant of other voices.

Title: Worth Watching
Review Text:
This is a good story from the other side of the spectrum which gives audience a chance to veer away from the long standing narrative of EDSA.

Direk Yap did not hide the real truth behind MIM. In fact, he is transparent declaring in a recent interview that, "This is a family in crisis film..." and is to be appreciated from the perspective of the maids, primarily the three Yayas - Biday (Beverly Salviejo), Lucy (Elizabeth Oropesa), and Santa (Karla Estrada). He also did not conceal the fact that the Marcos family had a direct hand in the making of the film, admitting in the same interview that Senator Imee Marcos deleted some from the original script, added some of her own, and approved the final script. Senator Imee Marcos is also the Executive Producer. It is in these regards that those behind MIM are honest and transparent as to the intentions of the movie.

And yeah, the number of ratings gives justice that this movie is indeed worth watching for Filipinos.

Title: The last 72 hrs....
Review Text:
If you're expecting a political thriller or a historical biopic, this is not it.

While based on true accounts, this is not about flipping the EDSA narrative at all. It is not to glorify the first family nor to make them heroes. So all the fuss about historical revisionism as far as we can see, is much ado about nothing.

What you'll get instead is a powerful tearjerker that exposes the Marcoses at their most vulnerable - during their last 72 hours in Malacañang. Even if you're apathetic about the Marcoses, you will still be moved by how Direk Darryl Yap. Is the film perfect? That's too generous of a statement. But it's very well-done.

The film is not a hagiography of the Marcoses but it shows them in a more humane light without completely absolving them of their sins.

It is a story of family, of love, and of hope. And that's something we can all root for..

Title: Good
Review Text:
RECIPEClassic Bananas Foster

By Poppy Tooker Fine Cooking Issue 106

Scott Phillips

(6 ratings)Read Reviews

Save to Recipe Box

Print

Add Recipe Note

Servings: six to eight.

Created at Brennan's restaurant in New Orleans in 1951, this classic dessert was named after loyal customer Richard Foster. Firm, ripe bananas are sautéed in a rum-infused caramel sauce, then flambéed in front of diners and spooned over vanilla ice cream. For extra pyrotechnics, throw a pinch of cinnamon onto the sauce as it flames.

Read the Test Kitchen blog for tips on flambéing safely.

Ingredients2 oz. (4 Tbs.) unsalted butter1 cup lightly packed dark brown sugar1/2 tsp. Ground cinnamon1/4 cup banana liqueur4 firm-ripe bananas, peeled, halved lengthwise, then halved crosswise1/4 cup amber rum, such as Old New Orleans or Goslings1 pint vanilla ice cream

Nutritional Information

PreparationIn a 12-inch skillet, melt the butter over medium heat. Stir in the brown sugar and cinnamon and cook until moist, about 1 minute. Add the banana liqueur and cook, stirring continuously, until the grainy texture disappears and the mixture rolls off the spoon in a steady stream, 1 to 2 minutes. Put the banana quarters rounded side down in the pan. Cook until the bananas begin to soften, 2 to 3 minutes.

Turn the bananas onto their flat sides. Remove the pan from the heat and pour in the rum. Set the pan over high heat and carefully ignite the rum with a long match or grill lighter. Gently shake the pan until the flame subsides. Remove from the heat.

Place a generous scoop of ice cream in 6 to 8 individual heatproof dessert bowls. Arrange 2 to 3 pieces of sautéed banana around each scoop of ice cream. Spoon on the sauce and serve immediately.

Title: The Other Side of History
Review Text:
For a very long time history books and the opposition mainly pictured the Marcos family as despicable and evil, and that Cory Aquino was the one who led the "peaceful" revolution that led to the overthrow of the Marcos Regime. Most of the Filipino people, if not all, were fooled into believing the narrative and lies that the left, the rebels and communists, NPA sympathizers, oligarchs, and student activists peddled. (And now they are going to IMDB to give this movie a low rating because that's what losers do)

The movie showed the other side of that story. The director, Darryl Yap, is successful in making the acting, the story, closer to reality by inserting old video footages of the real happenings around the time of EDSA Revolution in 1986. Yap was able to show the Marcoses as humans who have emotions, too. They were betrayed, frustrated, scared, and feared for their lives as the revolution is not really as peaceful as the opposition claims it to be. It was chaotic and bloody.

The best thing about this movie is that the information used to create this masterpiece came from a very reliable source -- one of the maids of the Marcoses in Malacañang. She was able to get herself out of the chaos in the palace by jumping into the Pasig River.

The movie is a roller coaster ride of emotions. It made me cry and laugh and mad at times. IT IS THE BEST.
